results.headline: Keeping His Secrets Well Up His Sleeve
results.summary_short: The documentary “Deceptive Practice: The Mysteries and Mentors of Ricky Jay” invites viewers to join one of Mr. Jay’s magical mystery tours. But don’t expect him to reveal where that coin went.
results.display_title: Deceptive Practices: The Mysteries and Mentors of Ricky Jay

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Deceptive Practices: The Mysteries and Mentors of Ricky Jay

results.headline: When Small Appliances Misbehave
results.summary_short: The newest episode of the parody franchise “Scary Movie” mines “Paranormal Activity,” “Black Swan” and “Rise of the Planet of the Apes” for a few laughs.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Scary Movie 5

results.headline: A Temperament for Trouble and a Nose for Fine Whisky
results.summary_short: In Ken Loach’s “Angels’ Share,” a hot-headed hooligan from Glasgow’s underclass turns out to have an extraordinary talent for identifying different varieties of whisky.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Angels' Share

results.headline: Skateboard Rebels Behind the Iron Curtain
results.summary_short: “This Ain’t California,” a “hybrid documentary,” chronicles the underground skateboarding scene in East Germany during the 1980s.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of This Ain't California

results.headline: Horror at Every Turn of a Dark Cyberjungle
results.summary_short: “Disconnect,” with Jason Bateman and Hope Davis, offers a montage of overlapping stories about thievery, humiliation and exposed secrets on the Internet.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Disconnect

results.headline: Twirling in Oklahoma, a Dervish for Love
results.summary_short: Paris, and Oklahoma, are wonderlands in Terrence Malick’s newest film, a spiritually minded romance starring Ben Affleck, Olga Kurylenko and Javier Bardem.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of To the Wonder

results.headline: Her Woody Allen Obsession
results.summary_short: The central character in “Paris Manhattan” spills her problems to a poster of Woody Allen, whose disembodied voice responds with lines from his movies.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Paris Manhattan

results.headline: The Apocalypse, for Laughs
results.summary_short: In Todd Berger’s comedy, Julia Stiles and David Cross play one of four Los Angeles couples whose weekly brunch is interrupted by a large-scale catastrophe.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of It's a Disaster

results.headline: Eyeing That Empty Seat
results.summary_short: In “Arcadia,” a film directed by Olivia Silver that opens on Friday in Brooklyn, three children grow ever more suspicious about their father’s intentions during a family road trip.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Arcadia

results.headline: Autographs Are Far Less of a Mess
results.summary_short: “Antiviral” is the first feature film directed by Brandon Cronenberg, the son of David Cronenberg.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Antiviral

results.headline: That Rookie at First Is in a New Position
results.summary_short: “42,” Brian Helgeland’s new film about Jackie Robinson, is blunt, simple and sentimental, using time-tested methods to teach a clear and rousing lesson.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 42

results.headline: Two Lonely Souls in Temporary Shelter
results.summary_short: In “Stranger Things,” a young woman arrives in an English seaside village to clear out her dead mother’s house, and finds an unexpected resident.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Stranger Things

results.headline: A Jilted Lover Unleashed in Paris
results.summary_short: “Simon Killer” is Antonio Campos’s tale of a recently dumped American looking for distraction in Paris.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Simon Killer

results.headline: A Visitor Disrupts a Beach Town Full of Secrets
results.summary_short: Harold Guskin’s “Down the Shore” centers on an amusement park worker, the woman he loves, and the man who married her.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Down the Shore

results.headline: Worms, a Botanist and Pigs. Sounds Like a Love Story.
results.summary_short: In “Upstream Color,” a man and a woman find each other as part of a plot where little is straightforward.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Upstream Color

results.headline: You Are Getting Sleepy. Where’d You Hide the Goya?
results.summary_short: In “Trance,” directed by Danny Boyle, an auction house employee gets caught up in an art heist.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Trance

results.headline: Young Man’s Wobbly Steps to Independence
results.summary_short: In “The Story of Luke” a high-functioning autistic man faces enormous changes to his sheltered life.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Story of Luke

results.headline: Be Careful What You Wish For
results.summary_short: An ancient kettle with magical powers tests a broke couple’s bond in Ramaa Mosley’s modern fable about money.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Brass Teapot

results.headline: Destroying a City With Hate
results.summary_short: Maria Iliou’s documentary “Smyrna: The Destruction of a Cosmopolitan City” recounts the burning of a religiously diverse Ottoman port by the Turks.
results.display_title: Smyrna: The Destruction of a Cosmopolitan City - 1900-1922

results.headline: Remembering the Side of the ’60s That Wasn’t All Peace and Love
results.summary_short: Robert Redford’s “Company You Keep,” which also features Julie Christie and Susan Sarandon, follows 1960s radicals in later life.
